awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Accelerator Physics and Synchrotron Radiation Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in Physics at Cornel University.  The site will support twelve undergraduate students per year in research projects in accelerator physics and synchrotron radiation science.  The student participants have full access to the resources of the Cornell Laboratory for Accelerator-based Sciences and Education (CLASSE) and the University, and will work closely with experienced researchers. Although the research scope of this REU program is focused on understanding the fundamental physics of beams and accelerators and the uses of the radiation they produce, the techniques and technologies utilized are applicable to a much wider range of scientific careers. In addition, each student is asked to participate in one of the outreach programs at the Laboratory, teaching them to communicate the scientific ideas with the public and exposing them to the outreach prospects at their home institutions, through the Society of Physics Students (SPS) chapters and other outlets.

The Cornell Laboratory has an international reputation for research, with a constellation of programs including accelerator physics, synchrotron radiation research, and microwave superconductivity. The students will work on a range of projects that advance the Laboratory's scientific mission, further their education and training, and heighten their interest in pursuing careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. Students will also attend lectures on wide topics in the accelerator physics and X-ray sciences; take part in talks and hands-on activities that introduce various frontiers of physics research with the larger group of REU groups on campus; and attend events addressing social and ethical issues in scientific research and conduct.  These joint activities will provide an environment that fosters networking of the future scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Particle accelerators, the cutting-edge discovery vessels, are at the forefront of intellectual and technological human endeavors. Increasing numbers of researchers rely on these complex machines to push the frontiers of physics, biology, material science, and medicine. However, there presently exists a need for more accelerator scientists and engineers in the United States relative to other regions like Europe. Addressing this crucial need, the Cornell Laboratory of Accelerator-Based Sciences and Education and its predecessor Laboratory of Nuclear Studies established and successfully operated an REU Site in Accelerator Science and related disciplines for nearly three decades.

As funded by this award over the past six years, the Cornell program has provided 57 undergraduate participants with the opportunity to engage in a wide range of research projects, spanning from computational simulations to hands-on engineering and building tasks in accelerator physics and synchrotron radiation science. Fourteen additional students took advantage of this program over the same period, whose summer fellowships were covered by a different entity, the Center for Bright Beams, an NSF Science and Technology Center at Cornell University. In our program, we aim not to merely educate and train our student participants in the required skills and research tools but to ignite their passion by teaming them with their mentors in performing ongoing world-class research to foster a profound sense of accomplishment and camaraderie. To that end, students actively engage in lectures, tours, and discussions that provide a panoramic perspective and offer a comprehensive view of the field, exploring various career paths.

The nature of student activities encompasses a variety of projects led by experienced mentors, both faculty and staff scientists, who themselves are at the cutting edge of their research. For example, students design, prototype, and test new equipment for accelerator science research. They perform simulations and improve beam instrumentation to deepen our understanding of particle beams. The REU participants also contribute to designing and testing accelerator modules and components, such as sources, accelerating structures, and beam monitors, to enhance operational performance. Other projects involved the development of delivery and feedback systems for high-powered lasers, improving microwave superconductivity performance for accelerators, studying X-ray optical instruments and techniques for materials analysis, and applying those techniques to tackle specific questions in material science.

Throughout their research experience, participants acquire a variety of skills and knowledge. They become proficient in programming languages and develop expertise in computer-aided design, graphical analysis, data analysis, cryogenics, high vacuum technologies, laser technology, and X-ray and particle physics detection techniques. Students generate written reports at the end of their projects (available online on our website) and present their results orally. Many student projects have led to peer-reviewed publications in reputable journals and conference proceedings in accelerator science and related disciplines. 

The Research Experience for Undergraduates program in Accelerator Physics and Synchrotron Radiation Science at Cornell aims to achieve several important goals. It thoroughly educates students in modern research methodologies and laboratory techniques while enabling independent and collaborative research experiences. The program helps students explore their future career paths, motivating them to pursue careers in science and exposing those from other fields to the world of scientific research. Moreover, the program strongly emphasizes enhancing students' written and oral communication skills, enabling them to convey their research findings effectively. Diversity and broadening participation in physics are a priority at our REU Site as they enrich the research environment, stimulating different perspectives and ideas. Our cohort of students supported by this award over the last six years represents a diverse group, with more than half being women, first-generation college students, minorities, or students from smaller undergraduate institutions.
